<Summary source="https://www.chartstorm.info/p/weekly-s-and-p500-chartstorm-1-february">
# Summary of "Weekly S&P500 ChartStorm - 1 February 2026"

**Source:** Chartstorm.info  
**Date:** February 1, 2026  
**Author:** Callum Thomas

## Key Facts and Observations:

1. **January 2026 Performance:** Stocks closed up in January, with equal-weight indices outperforming cap-weight indices.

2. **Positive January Signal:** According to the analysis, a positive January is considered a positive sign for the rest of the year.

3. **Market Rotations Observed:**
   - Rotation appears to be occurring out of cryptocurrency into precious metals
   - Rotation from growth/tech stocks to value/cyclical stocks

4. **Market Characterization:** The author characterizes the current market movement as a "bullish rotation" or "broadening bull" market.

5. **Risk Areas Identified:** The article notes there are "a few risk spots to keep tabs on," specifically:
   - Price action in crypto
   - Tech/growth sector performance

6. **Positive Indicators:** Relative strength in cyclical parts of the market suggests the prospect of "bullish broadening"

7. **Overall Assessment:** The year has gotten off to a "decent start" with gains and bullish rotations in January.

**Note:** The article content appears to be truncated at the end ("n. b. see the new and refreshed"), so this summary reflects only the information provided in the extracted text.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/01/stock-market-today-live-updates.html">
# Summary of S&P 500 Article from February 1, 2026

## Key Market Movements

**Date:** February 1, 2026 (Monday market open)

**S&P 500 Performance:**
- S&P 500 futures dipped 0.3% (later updated to 0.4%)
- Nasdaq-100 futures fell 0.5% (later 0.6%)
- Dow Jones Industrial Average futures initially gained 19 points (0.04%), later lost 112 points (0.2%)

## Major Market Drivers

**Bitcoin and Precious Metals Volatility:**
- Bitcoin dropped below $80,000 for the first time since April 2026, later trading above $78,000
- Silver plunged around 30% on Friday (previous trading day) - worst one-day performance since 1980
  - Silver had more than doubled over the past 12 months prior to the drop
- Gold dropped around 9% on Friday, falling below $5,000 an ounce (article later states "nearly 10%")
- On Monday, spot gold and spot silver were down more than 3% each
- Losses attributed to "a firmer dollar and profit-taking"

**Nvidia Developments:**
- Nvidia shares down more than 1% in premarket
- The Wall Street Journal reported Nvidia's plans to invest $100 billion into OpenAI had stalled, with chipmaker executives expressing doubt about the deal
- Despite the stalled $100 billion deal, Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang stated Saturday: "We are going to make a huge investment in OpenAI. I believe in OpenAI, the work that they do is incredible, they are one of the most consequential companies of our time"

## Corporate Earnings and Announcements

**Earnings Season:**
- More than 100 S&P 500 companies scheduled to report earnings this week, including Amazon and Alphabet
- Deutsche Bank strategists noted earnings growth is on track to be the strongest in four years
- Some high-profile post-earnings sell-offs occurred (e.g., Microsoft)

**Disney:**
- Reported fiscal first-quarter earnings that beat expectations
- Earned adjusted $1.63 per share on revenue of $25.98 billion
- Analysts expected $1.57 per share on revenue of $25.74 billion
- Shares up more than 3%
- Strength driven by parks and streaming

**Oracle:**
- Announced plans to raise up to $50 billion in 2026 through debt and equity financing
- Purpose: to build additional capacity to meet contracted demand from largest Oracle Cloud Infrastructure customers, including AMD and Meta
- Shares down more than 3%

**Autodesk:**
- JPMorgan upgraded to overweight from neutral
- New target price of $319 implies 26% upside
- Analyst cited accelerating cloud adoption and AI integration

## Economic and Political Context

**Federal Reserve:**
- Stocks fell in previous session after President Donald Trump nominated Kevin Warsh as Federal Reserve chairman
- If confirmed, Warsh would replace Jerome Powell later in 2026

**Jobs Report:**
- January U.S. jobs report due Friday morning
- Economists polled by Dow Jones expect 55,000 jobs were added in January
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.xtb.com/int/market-analysis/news-and-research/us500-rebounds-after-the-sell-off-wall-street-earnings-season-analysis">
# Summary of XTB.com Article on Q4 2025 Earnings Season

## Key Facts and Statistics:

**Current Earnings Season Performance (Q4 2025):**
- Approximately one-third of S&P 500 companies have reported
- 75% of S&P 500 companies beat EPS forecasts
- 65% surprised positively on revenue
- Blended year-over-year earnings growth rate: 11.9%
- If this pace holds, it would mark a fifth consecutive quarter of double-digit earnings growth
- On December 31, consensus had implied only 8.3% earnings growth for Q4 (vs. current ~11.9%)
- Six sectors are tracking stronger earnings outcomes than at year-end

**Profit Margins:**
- S&P 500 blended net profit margin for Q4 2025: 13.2%
- This would be the highest net profit margin since FactSet began tracking in 2009
- Previous record was 13.1%, set in Q3 2025
- Only five sectors are currently above their five-year average net margins

**Sector-Specific Margin Performance:**
- Technology and Industrials showing strongest performance
- Real Estate margins declined to 33.5% from 35.1% (year-over-year)
- Energy essentially flat at 7.8% year-over-year
- Industrials expanded sequentially to 12.5% vs. 10.5% (Q4 vs. Q3)
- Utilities declined sequentially to 12.9% vs. 17.1%

**Valuation Metrics:**
- S&P 500 forward 12-month P/E: 22.2
- This is above both the 5-year average and 10-year average (specific numbers not provided)

**Q1 2026 Guidance:**
- Described as "steady rather than exuberant"
- Characterized as "constructive, but not euphoric"

**2026 Outlook:**
- Consensus expects net profit margins to climb even higher in 2026 (specific projected figures mentioned but not fully detailed in excerpt)

**Technical Analysis:**
- S&P 500 futures (US 500) have reclaimed the 50-day EMA on daily chart
- Currently hovering near 6,950

## Key Opinions/Analysis from Source:

The article (from XTB.com, a trading platform) suggests that:
- Expectations were set conservatively, while companies showed stronger operational resilience than priced in
- The narrative that costs are rapidly eroding corporate profitability is being challenged by historic high margins
- The record margin is driven by a few large, highly profitable segments rather than broad-based improvement
- The bigger risk for equities isn't the earnings backdrop itself, but that at current valuation levels, investors will demand near-perfect execution
- Any earnings stumble could carry larger price impact than in a lower-multiple environment
- If margins continue to deliver on projected trajectory, high valuations may remain defensible
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.cnn.com/2026/01/01/investing/what-to-expect-stock-market-2026">
# Summary of CNN Article: "What to expect from stocks in 2026"

**Key Facts and Statistics:**

- The S&P 500 ended 2025 at 6,845.5 points
- The index gained more than 16% in 2025 and recorded 39 new record highs across the year
- The S&P 500 fell as much as 19% in April 2025 due to Trump's aggressive tariffs before rebounding
- Historical pattern: When the S&P 500 has gained at least 15% in a year, the following year's returns have averaged about 8%, with an average decline of roughly 14% at some point before rebounding (according to Adam Turnquist, LPL Financial)
- Gold had its best year since 1979 in 2025

**Wall Street Analyst Forecasts for Year-End 2026:**

1. **Bank of America**: 7,100 points (3.72% gain)
2. **Deutsche Bank**: 8,000 points (16.87% gain)
3. **Ed Yardeni (Yardeni Research)**: 7,700 points (12.5% gain)
4. **Christopher Harvey (CIBC Capital Markets)**: roughly 8.8% gain
5. **Goldman Sachs** (Peter Oppenheimer): Expects lower index returns than 2025, but remains constructive on equities

All forecasts reviewed by CNN predict positive gains, though with a wide range of estimates.

**Bullish Factors Cited:**

- AI-driven growth and "supercycle" fueling record capital expenditures and earnings expansion
- Expected Fed rate cuts in 2026
- Resilient corporate earnings growth
- Wealthier consumers continue spending in K-shaped economy
- Stock market rally broadening beyond AI (Dow began outpacing Nasdaq in November)
- Economy remains resilient with inflation benign, interest rates trending lower, and earnings trending higher

**Risk Factors Cited:**

- High valuations (stocks becoming increasingly expensive)
- Uncertainty about Trump's pick for Federal Reserve Chair
- Geopolitical tensions and tariff concerns
- Potential for stubborn inflation complicating Fed rate-cutting path
- Concerns about returns on AI spending and potential AI bubble
- US-Mexico-Canada trade agreement expiring in 2026
- Rising long-term borrowing costs and large government deficits
- Fed independence concerns
- Credit market concerns
- Labor market health affecting consumer spending

**Notable Opinions:**

- Hardika Singh (Fundstrat): "This year's gains have shown that the bull market is all gas, no brakes. And there are few solid reasons to believe this run can't extend into the next year."
- Terry Sandven (US Bank Asset Management): "Inflation is benign, interest rates are trending lower and earnings are trending higher, and that's goldilocks for stocks."
- Ed Yardeni: Places odds of a severe correction or bear market at 20%
- Dan Ives (Wedbush Securities): Top five stock picks for 2026 are Nvidia, Microsoft, Apple, Tesla, and Palantir
- Fabio Bassi (JPMorgan Chase): "Overall, the market environment remains fragile, and investors must navigate a landscape where risk and resilience coexist."
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://finance.yahoo.com/news/wall-street-analysts-predict-9-114500864.html">
# Article Summary: Wall Street analysts predict 9% returns for S&P 500 in 2026

**Date:** January 18, 2026  
**Source:** Yahoo Finance  
**Author:** Rebecca Holland

## Key Facts and Statistics:

1. **Analyst Predictions:** Bloomberg reported in late 2025 that Wall Street analysts are predicting 9% returns on the S&P 500 in 2026, with the possibility of double-digit returns.

2. **Historical Context:** If the S&P 500 achieves four years of double-digit returns, this would mark the first time since the 1990s dot-com bubble.

3. **Stock Ownership Levels:** According to Federal Reserve data, 45% of American households' financial assets are tied to direct and indirect stock holdings - the highest level ever.

4. **Historical Risk Comparison:** CNN notes that Americans' stock ownership has now surpassed the levels of the late 1990s, just before the dot-com bubble burst.

## Factors Driving the Market Rally:
- Cooling inflation rate
- Fed's interest rate policy
- Continued corporate profits
- Resilience of the stock market in 2025 (which beat early predictions of a bear market after Trump's trade war initially rocked investor confidence)

## Risk Factors Mentioned:
- Looming AI bubble
- Doubts about the President's next moves
- Potential for tech stocks to tumble
- Market volatility due to uncertainty

## Named Expert Opinion:

**Michael Kantrowitz, Chief Investment Strategist at Piper Sandler & Co.** (speaking to Bloomberg):
- Noted there has been "a great amount of uncertainty in the last five years, and particularly this year"
- Stated that when there's uncertainty, "investors are very myopic and reactive to different data points and it doesn't take much to change the opinion and consensus"
- Revealed that his firm no longer issues annual forecasts due to this uncertainty

## Article's General Perspective:
The article takes a cautious tone, emphasizing that "forecasts are not guarantees" and warning that "the market rarely moves in straight lines," despite the optimistic analyst predictions.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.tker.co/p/wall-street-2026-stock-market-outlook">
# Summary of "Wall Street's 2026 outlook for stocks 🔭"

**Source:** Tker.co  
**Author:** Sam Ro, CFA  
**Date:** Not clearly specified (appears to be late 2025 based on references to Dec. 5 close)

## Key Facts and Statistics:

### Year-End 2026 S&P 500 Targets:
Wall Street strategists' targets range from **7,100 to 8,000**, implying returns between **3.3% and 16.4%** from the Dec. 5 close (context suggests this is Dec. 5, 2025).

The article notes that the market rarely delivers an average return in a given year, with a **standard deviation of nearly 20 percentage points** around the mean annual total return for the S&P 500 (per Data Trek's Nick Colas).

### Individual Firm Forecasts (13 strategists):

1. **Bank of America:** 7,100 (EPS: $310) - implies ~5% price return
2. **Societe Generale:** 7,300 (EPS: $310)
3. **Barclays:** 7,400 (EPS: $305)
4. **CFRA:** 7,400
5. **UBS:** 7,500 (EPS: $309)
6. **JPMorgan:** 7,500 (EPS: $315)
7. **Goldman Sachs:** 7,600 (EPS: $305) - forecasts 12% EPS growth with 7% revenue growth
8. **KKR:** 7,600 (EPS: $303)
9. **Yardeni:** 7,700 (EPS: $310)
10. **Fundstrat:** 7,700 (EPS: $307)
11. **RBC:** 7,750 (EPS: $311)
12-13. Two additional firms mentioned but details cut off

### Consensus Expectations:
- **Earnings growth for 2026:** 14% (consensus)
- **Valuation multiples:** Expected to remain in 22-23x forward earnings range (per KKR)
- **Revenue growth:** 7% (per Goldman Sachs)
- **Profit margin expansion:** 70 basis points (per Goldman Sachs)

## Key Drivers for 2026 (Named Sources):

**Economic Tailwinds:**
- Fiscal stimulus from the "One Big Beautiful Bill Act" (expected to add 0.9% to GDP)
- Continued Fed rate cuts
- More friendly trade policy than 2025
- Increased AI capex spending

**Economic Challenges:**
- Inflation expected to remain above Fed's 2% target
- Labor markets expected to remain cool as companies use AI for complex tasks

**Valuation Concerns:**
- More conservative strategists expect P/E ratio contraction from elevated levels
- Returns would be primarily driven by earnings growth rather than multiple expansion

**Midterm Election Year Pattern:**
CFRA's Sam Stovall notes that midterm election years since 1946 have averaged:
- **18% intra-year drawdown** (highest of all four years in presidential cycle)
- **3.8% average annual price gain** (weakest of the four-year cycle)
- **55% frequency of positive returns** (versus 76% for other three years)

## Notable Opinions from Named Sources:

- **Bank of America:** Expects multiple contraction of about 10 points; earnings will "do the lift" in 2026
- **Goldman Sachs:** Believes "deregulation and broadening AI-related productivity gains remain underappreciated"
- **JPMorgan:** Sees "current elevated multiples correctly anticipating above-trend earnings growth"
- **Yardeni:** Expects "2026 will be just another year of the Roaring 2020s"
- **UBS:** Expects market consolidation first, then broadening rally from late Q1; sees "speed bump" as tariffs worsen growth-inflation mix temporarily

**Note:** The article text appears to be cut off at the end (RBC commentary is incomplete), so there may be additional forecasts not captured in this summary.
</Summary>

**Piazza Affari Opens in the Red Amid Global Market Declines**
Italian stock indices opened the week in negative territory on February 2, 2026. The FTSEMib declined 0.52% to 45,289 points, while the FTSE Italy All Share fell 0.54%, the FTSE Italy Mid Cap dropped 0.53%, and the FTSE Italy Star lost 0.65%. **Stock Market Outlook for February**
The Moscow Exchange Index closed January at +0.5%, just above 2,800 points, holding above key support levels but below resistance. Despite ongoing geopolitical uncertainty, the market failed to consolidate above 2,800, with the benchmark expected to target 3,000 points if positive external signals emerge or if the Central Bank of Russia reduces its key rate by 50 basis points on February 13. Among stocks, Southern Urals Gold outperformed the market with a January gain of +37%, closing above 0.73 rubles after an initial rally exceeding 80% and a peak near 1 ruble. A correction may end near 0.7 rubles, followed by a rebound driven by the upcoming state share auction and a potential resumption of the upward trend in gold prices. A technical rebound could reach resistance at 0.8 rubles, with a full-year target set at 0.95 rubles. In contrast, Lukoil underperformed with a -10% decline in January, though adjusted for 6% dividends, the net loss was -4%, still worse than the broader market due to uncertainty over the sale of foreign assets. Long-term valuation remains at 6,500 rubles, with a February target of recovery toward 5,600 rubles. The ruble strengthened by +3% against the USD in January, with USD/RUB falling to 75.73—the lowest since March 2023. In February, the currency is expected to stabilize amid expectations of a dovish monetary policy shift, rising imports, and declining exports, with projected levels of 80 for the dollar, 95 for the euro, and 11.5 for the yuan. According to Mikhail Zeltsier, equity market expert at 'BCS Mir Investitsii'.

**DAX - Slight Gain in January, But a Gain Nonetheless**
The DAX® ended January 2026 with a narrow gain of 0.2%, closing at 24,490 points—the year-end level from 2025—according to the 'January Barometer' indicator, which historically suggests the broader year's market performance. Despite falling below the previous day's close on Thursday, the index still managed a slight positive result. In contrast, the S&P 500® and Nasdaq-100® rose 1.4% and 1.2% respectively in January, indicating stronger momentum in U.S. markets. Technically, the DAX® is supported by the 50-day (24,326 points) and 200-day (23,953 points) moving averages, which act as key support levels. To negate recent warnings, German blue-chip stocks must reclaim previous resistance levels at 24,600 and 24,700 points. The analysis is provided by HSBC Continental Europe S.A., Germany, and includes disclaimers about transaction costs and investment risks.

**Australia shares lower at close of trade; S&P/ASX 200 down 1.02% By Investing.com**
On Monday, February 2, 2026, Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index closed 1.02% lower, driven by losses in the ASX All Ordinaries Gold, S&P/ASX 300 Metals & Mining, and S&P/ASX 200 Materials sectors. The biggest gainers on the S&P/ASX 200 were Contact Energy Ltd (ASX:CEN), up 7.46% to 8.50, Nine Entertainment Co Holdings Ltd (ASX:NEC), gaining 6.99% to 1.23, and Whitehaven Coal Ltd (ASX:WHC), rising 3.06% to 9.10. The biggest losers included Graincorp Ltd (ASX:GNC), which fell 13.19% to 6.25—its lowest level in three years—Newmont Corporation DRC (ASX:NEM), down 10.02% to 155.91, and Emerald Resources NL (ASX:EMR), declining 9.13% to 6.77. Falling stocks outnumbered advancing ones 908 to 347, with 326 stocks unchanged on the Sydney Stock Exchange. The S&P/ASX 200 VIX rose 12.46% to 12.58, marking a new 1-month high. In commodities, Gold Futures for April delivery dropped 1.75% to $4,662.26 per troy ounce, while March Crude Oil fell 5.44% to $61.66 per barrel and April Brent Oil declined 5.24% to $65.69 per barrel. The AUD/USD remained unchanged at 0.69, while AUD/JPY fell 0.44% to 107.28. The US Dollar Index Futures increased 0.21% to 97.06.

**Australia: Stocks Closed Lower as S&P/ASX 200 Fell 1.02%**
Australian stocks closed lower on Monday, with declines in the Gold, Metals & Mining, and Materials sectors driving the market down. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 1.02% at the close in Sydney. Contact Energy Ltd (ASX:CEN) led gains with a 7.46% rise, closing at 8.50, followed by Nine Entertainment Co Holdings Ltd (ASX:NEC), up 6.99% to 1.23, and Whitehaven Coal Ltd (ASX:WHC), which rose 3.06% to 9.10. The worst performers were Graincorp Ltd (ASX:GNC), which dropped 13.19% to 6.25—its lowest level in three years—Newmont Corporation DRC (ASX:NEM), down 10.02% to 155.91, and Emerald Resources NL (ASX:EMR), which fell 9.13% to 6.77. On the exchange, 908 stocks declined versus 347 advancing, with 326 unchanged. The S&P/ASX 200 VIX, measuring implied volatility of S&P/ASX 200 options, rose 12.46% to 12.58, marking a one-month high. Gold futures for April delivery fell 1.64% to $4,667.36 per troy ounce, while crude oil futures for March dropped 5.38% to $61.70 per barrel, and Brent crude for April declined 5.19% to $65.72 per barrel. The AUD/USD remained flat at 0.69, while AUD/JPY fell 0.45% to 107.27. The Dollar Futures Index dropped 0.21% to 97.06.

**[Investment Calendar] Major Capital Market Events Today**
On February 2, 2026, multiple significant events are scheduled in China's capital markets and related sectors. The 2026 Spring Festival travel season will begin on February 2 and end on March 13. The Supreme People's Procuratorate will hold a press conference at 10:00 a.m. to address 'special supervision on illegal异地执法 and profit-driven law enforcement and judicial practices.' The China Securities Regulatory Commission will officially launch nine new indices, including the CSI High-Grade Science and Technology Innovation Bond Index, on February 2. The China Southern Nuclear Clean Energy REIT will list on the Shanghai Stock Exchange on the same day. The import temporary tariff on whisky will be set at 5% starting February 2. The Shanghai Municipal Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference will open its 14th session on February 2. The Asia Virtual Reality XR Industry Expo (AWE Asia 2026) will be held from February 2 to 4 at the Singapore Expo. Additionally, 17 stocks are expected to face delisting, with a total of 3.088 billion shares and a combined market value of 60.179 billion yuan. The individual gold accumulation business at China Construction Bank will increase the minimum investment threshold to 1,500 yuan starting February 2 at 9:10 a.m.

**U.S. Stocks Plunge Nearly 5% as AI Bubble Fears Resurge Amid Strong Jobs Data and Rate Cut Doubts**
On February 20, 2026, U.S. stock markets experienced a sharp downturn, with all major indices closing lower. The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index plummeted nearly 5%, falling 317.96 points or 4.77% to close at 6,352.07. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 386 points to 45,752.26, the S&P 500 fell 103.4 points to 6,538.76, and the Nasdaq Composite plunged 486 points or 2.15% to 22,078.05. Despite Nvidia reporting strong Q3 results with 62% year-over-year revenue growth and better-than-expected EPS, the stock ended down 2.97% at $180.98, reversing gains and marking its worst monthly performance since March. Other AI-related stocks also declined sharply: Micron (-10.87%), Marvell (-5.71%), Microsoft (-1.78%), Netflix (-3.94%), and NetApp (-2.85%). Only a few stocks like Ninth City and NetEase rose. The S&P 11 sectors saw only consumer staples marginally positive; technology stocks led losses with a 2.66% drop. Market analysts attributed the sell-off to concerns over AI valuation bubbles, profit-taking, and a shift in sentiment due to the U.S. September nonfarm payroll report showing 119,000 new jobs—well above expectations—while the unemployment rate hit a 4-year high. Federal funds futures indicated a drop in the probability of a December rate cut to below 40%, reducing the likelihood of a rate cut and increasing uncertainty around monetary policy. This heightened fears of an AI bubble. In contrast, Asian markets rallied on Nvidia’s pre-market strength: Japan’s Nikkei 225 surged 1,286 points (2.65%) to 49,823, TOPIX rose 1.66%, and South Korea’s KOSPI gained 75.34 points (1.92%) to 4,004.85. Analysts like Rong Yishen of Qifa Investment and KKM Financial noted that the initial optimism from Nvidia’s report was overwhelmed by concerns over rate cuts, market liquidity, and potential AI growth slowdown. The market’s shift in sentiment suggests a broader reassessment of AI stocks’ valuations and future growth prospects. Future market movements will depend on Fed commentary, Taiwan’s stock performance, and semiconductor supply chain dynamics.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 01, 2026 02:32 AM
Source:[k.sina.com.cn](https://k.sina.com.cn/article_7857201856_1d45362c001901x8mw.html)

**S&P 500 Falls for Third Straight Day Despite January Gain**
The S&P 500 declined for the third consecutive day on Friday, closing down 0.43% to 6,939.03, marking its third straight losing session. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 179 points, or 0.36%, ending at 48,892.47. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite underperformed, falling 0.94% to close at 23,461.82. All three major indexes fell more than 1% at their session lows. Despite Friday’s losses and volatile trading during January, the S&P 500 still recorded a monthly gain for January 2026. Investors generally approved of President Donald Trump’s nomination of Kevin Warsh to lead the Federal Reserve, though technology stocks remained weak. The article was published on January 31, 2026, at 08:17 by Ammon News, a news agency based in Jordan.

**U.S. Stock Market Declines Amid Uncertainty Over Next Fed Chair and Rate Cut Expectations**
The U.S. stock market declined on January 30, 2026, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average closing at 48,892.47, down 179.09 points, and the Nasdaq Composite ending at 23,461.82, down 223.30 points. The S&P 500 also fell to 6,939.03, down 29.98 points. The downturn followed a stronger-than-expected December 2025 Producer Price Index (PPI) and the announcement by former President Donald Trump that Kevin Warsh, a known hawkish figure, would become the next Federal Reserve Chair. This shift increased uncertainty around future interest rate cuts, prompting investors to take profits. Sector-wise, telecommunications services rose while semiconductors and related manufacturing declined. SanDisk (SNDK) surged on strong second-quarter results and robust demand for AI data center memory chips. Apple (AAPL) rose despite concerns over memory price increases and supply constraints. Gold miner Newmont (NEM) fell sharply as the dollar strengthened and gold prices dropped, with silver prices plunging over 30% at one point. Silver producers such as Hudbay Minerals (HL), Coeur Mining (CDE), and Pan American Silver (PAAS) saw significant sell-offs. Footwear company Deckers Outdoor (DECK) surged after reporting better-than-expected earnings and raising its full-year outlook, driven by strong performance in brands like UGG and HOKA. Federal Reserve Governor Michelle Bowman indicated in a CNBC interview that Kevin Warsh is likely to succeed her as Fed Chair upon her term's expiration on March 31, 2026.
Original language: ja
Publish date: January 30, 2026 11:15 PM
Source:[Investing.com 日本](https://jp.investing.com/news/stock-market-news/article-1404263)

**TSX loses over 1,000 points as gold, mining stocks drop; U.S. markets also down**
Canada's S&P/TSX composite index dropped 1,092.61 points to close at 31,923.52 on Friday, January 30, 2026, driven by losses in the basic materials sector, particularly gold and mining stocks. The decline followed U.S. President Donald Trump's announcement that Kevin Warsh would replace Jerome Powell as Federal Reserve chair. Allan Small, senior investment adviser at iA Private Wealth, attributed the sell-off to Warsh’s perceived hawkish stance, which strengthened the U.S. dollar and pressured gold and other metals. The April gold contract fell US$609.70 to US$4,745.10 per ounce. U.S. markets also declined: the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 179.09 points to 48,892.47, the S&P 500 fell 29.98 points to 6,939.03, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 223.30 points to 23,461.82. Small noted that Warsh’s appointment was seen as a positive for Fed independence, reducing fears of political interference. The Canadian dollar weakened to 73.74 U.S. cents from 73.99 U.S. cents the previous day. Crude oil prices also fell, with the March contract down 21 cents to US$65.21 per barrel. The report was published by The Canadian Press and The Star.

**S&P 500 Declines in Afternoon Trading Amid Market Volatility**
The S&P 500 declined by 0.45% to 6,937.86 points by 20:00 CET during NYSE trading on Friday, January 30, 2026, resulting in a loss of 54.859 million EUR in market value. The index had previously dropped 0.378% to 6,942.66 points at the start of the Friday session, after closing at 6,969.01 points the previous day. The daily high was 6,964.09 points, and the daily low was 6,893.48 points. On a year-to-date basis, the S&P 500 has risen 1.16% in 2026, with a year-to-date high of 7,002.28 and a year-to-date low of 6,789.05. Since the beginning of 2025, the index has increased by 0.211% from 6,896.24 points on December 30, 2025, and 6,822.34 points on October 30, 2025. The S&P 500 reached 6,071.17 points on January 30, 2025. Among the top gainers in the index were Robert Half (+26.91% to $34.38), Deckers Outdoor (+16.94% to $116.82), Verizon (+10.07% to $43.82), SanDisk (+8.47% to $585.00), and Charter A (+6.24% to $203.47). The worst performers were KLA-Tencor (-13.87% to $1,451.04), AppLovin (-12.78% to $496.47), Western Digital (-11.34% to $246.83), Newmont (-11.20% to $112.71), and Take Two (-10.09% to $215.12). NVIDIA holds the highest market capitalization in the S&P 500 at 3.898 billion EUR, with 23,583,558 shares traded. According to FactSet estimates, First Republic Bank has the lowest price-to-earnings ratio (P/E) of 0.10 in 2026, while Lyondellbasell Industries is projected to offer the highest dividend yield of 10.03% in 2026.

**Nasdaq Drops Over 150 Points Amid Weakening Investor Sentiment, Fear & Greed Index Still in 'Greed' Zone**
On Thursday, January 30, 2026, the Nasdaq Composite Index dropped by more than 150 points amid deteriorating investor sentiment, though the CNN Fear & Greed Index remained in the 'Greed' zone at 61.7, down from 64 the previous day. The U.S. stock market showed mixed performance: the Dow Jones rose about 56 points to close at 49,071.56, the S&P 500 declined 0.13% to 6,969.01, and the Nasdaq fell 0.72% to 23,685.12. Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT) shares plunged nearly 10%, marking their worst session since March 2020, after reporting a slowdown in cloud growth. ServiceNow (NYSE:NOW) dropped 10% despite positive fourth-quarter results and revenue. In contrast, Meta Platforms (NASDAQ:META) surged over 10% on strong first-quarter revenue guidance, and IBM (NYSE:IBM) rose more than 5% on better-than-expected earnings and outlook. Economic indicators showed U.S. initial jobless claims rose to 209,000, exceeding the forecast of 205,000. The trade deficit widened sharply to $56.8 billion in November from $29.2 billion in October. Wholesale inventories increased 0.2% to $915 billion in November, matching the previous month’s pace. Factory orders rose 2.7% month-over-month to $621.6 billion in November. Most S&P 500 sectors rose, with real estate, communication services, and financials leading gains, while consumer discretionary and technology sectors declined. Investors awaited earnings reports from Verizon Communications (NYSE:VZ), Chevron (NYSE:CVX), and ExxonMobil (NYSE:XOM). The CNN Fear & Greed Index measures market sentiment on a scale of 0 to 100, with 0 indicating extreme fear and 100 extreme greed. It is calculated from seven equally weighted indicators.

**Analyst who predicted S&P 500 rally offers 2026 warning**
Ryan Detrick, Chief Market Strategist at Carson Group, accurately predicted the S&P 500 would reach 6900 by December 29, 2025, closely matching the actual closing value of 6896. According to data from YCharts, the S&P 500 posted a 17.3% return in December 2025, with monthly returns ranging from -5.75% in March to 6.15% in May, resulting in a full-year gain. Detrick anticipates double-digit gains for 2026, forecasting a 12% to 15% increase, but issued a warning about the potential for a substantial intra-year pullback in 2026, citing the historical volatility of the middle year of the four-year presidential cycle. The Stock Trader's Almanac, referenced in the article, notes that markets typically perform best in the first and final years of a presidential cycle due to election-year promises and first-year optimism. Since 2000, analysts have missed S&P 500 forecasts by an average of 14.1%, according to Bespoke.

**U.S. Stocks Face Unprecedented Risk on Record 'Quadruple Witching Day' as $7.1 Trillion in Options Expire**
On Thursday, U.S. stock indices closed higher across the board, but market sentiment remained tense as traders anticipated an unprecedented market volatility event. The upcoming 'quadruple witching day' on Friday, December 19, 2025, marked the largest in history, with $7.1 trillion (approximately NT$223.8 trillion) in expiring options contracts—surpassing all prior records. The majority of this, about $5 trillion, was tied to the S&P 500 index, with an additional $880 billion from individual stock options. This volume equates to 10.2% of the Russell 3000 Index’s total market capitalization, significantly impacting market liquidity and short-term price movements. Analysts warn that the massive expiration could trigger heightened volatility due to settlement and hedging activities, or alternatively, create a 'pinning effect' that temporarily suppresses price swings. The S&P 500’s 6,800-point level is identified as a critical technical threshold—its ability to hold this level will determine whether the bullish trend from 2025 continues. Technical analysis from SpotGamma shows the index is within a 'gamma pressure zone' between 6,700 and 6,900 points. A close above 6,800 could signal the start of a 'Santa Claus rally.' SpotGamma recommends long investors consider December 31, 2025, call spreads near 6,900, while short-side investors may opt for put options expiring in February or March 2026 to mitigate time decay during holidays. The S&P 500 rose 0.79% to close at 6,770 points on Thursday, up about 15% year-to-date.

**Global Markets Seek Balance After Super Wednesday | Investing.com**
On Thursday (11), Brazil's Bovespa index initially rose following news related to Motta but reversed in the final minutes, closing slightly down 0.13% at 157,981.13 points, with R$25 billion in trading volume. The Brazilian real initially performed poorly, registering its worst morning performance among the world’s 33 strongest currencies, amid speculation about Flávio’s political candidacy. Later, as the 'price' of his candidacy was assessed through 'dosimetry,' the U.S. dollar slowed its rise to 0.26%, trading at R$5.4349, fueled by hopes of reduced fragmentation on the right-wing political front. On Friday (12), U.S. futures markets showed mixed performance after investor rotation from technology stocks into value and cyclical stocks pushed the Dow Jones and S&P 500 to new record highs. Following the initial market reaction to the FOMC and COPOM meetings on Super Wednesday, market participants are awaiting new commentary. The COPOM’s more hawkish tone has raised concerns: will interest rate cuts occur in January 2026 or only in March? Economic indicators such as retail sales and GDP show weakening momentum, and real interest rates are becoming excessive, already affecting default rates. Many market participants believe there is room for a rate cut next month. Meanwhile, in Congress, tensions between the Executive and the Supreme Federal Court (STF), along with the Legislative branch’s weak institutional standing, have caused discomfort. Internationally, Nicolás Maduro’s room for maneuver is shrinking, especially after Maria Corina’s visit to Oslo and her Nobel Prize recognition, signaling that his time may be nearing an end. The FOMC’s decision appears to have been interpreted by the market as a 'pause' in rate hikes.

--- Deep Research Analysis ---
### February 2026 S&P 500 Outlook Through March

**Current Status**  
As of early February 2026, the S&P 500 trades near 6,970, down from its recent record above 7,000 [1][11][16]. This pullback follows President Trump's nomination of Kevin Warsh as next Federal Reserve Chair (effective May 2026), which triggered safe-hasset sell-offs and equity volatility [1][3][7][9]. Despite this, the index remains **up ~1% YTD** and near all-time highs, supported by robust earnings expectations [3][6][13].

#### Federal Reserve Impact
- **March Meeting**: Markets price in an **85.1% chance of no rate change** in March, maintaining the current 3.5%-3.75% range [1][4]. Two Fed governors recently dissented favoring a cut, reflecting internal policy divergence [11].
- **Warsh Uncertainty**: Historically hawkish but recently dovish, Warsh's nomination sparks concerns about Fed independence amid Trump's public pressure for rate cuts [2][9][19]. Markets will scrutinize his Congressional testimony for policy clues.
- **Key Data Watch**: The February 6 jobs report (forecast: +64K payrolls) and January inflation data could shift rate expectations. Weak labor data might accelerate cuts; strength could delay easing until June [4][6][10].

#### Earnings Influence
- **2026 Growth**: Analysts project **15% earnings growth** for S&P 500 companies [4][6][13][15], with tech sector profits expected to surge 27% [13].
- **Q4 2025 Performance**: 76.5% of early reporters beat expectations, but reactions were uneven. Microsoft's cloud disappointment weighed on markets, while Meta's strength provided support [4][6][16].
- **Tech Catalyst**: Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, and Nvidia's upcoming reports (late Jan-early Feb) are critical for sustaining the AI-driven rally. Capital expenditure guidance on AI infrastructure will be closely watched [3][6][13][20].
- **Valuation Risk**: Trading at 22x forward earnings, high concentration in tech megacaps makes the market vulnerable to earnings misses [8][15][19].

#### March Projections & Catalysts
- **Bull Case (7,100-7,200)**: Requires:  
  ✓ Strong tech earnings with robust AI spending outlook [6][13]  
  ✓ Reassuring Fed messaging on policy continuity [4][11]  
  ✓ Geopolitical de-escalation (e.g., U.S.-Iran tensions) [14][17]  
- **Bear Case (6,700-6,800)**: Risks include:  
  ✗ Earnings misses from key AI players [4][16]  
  ✗ Warsh nomination fueling policy uncertainty [2][7][10]  
  ✗ Inflation rebound delaying rate cuts [5][17]  
- **Base Case**: Choppy consolidation near 7,000, with **5-8% upside potential by March-end** if earnings momentum holds and Fed fears ease [11][15][19]. Technical support sits at 6,800 [7].

#### Analyst Consensus
- **Kalshi Prediction Market**: 19% probability of S&P 500 reaching 7,600-7,800 by December 2026 [12][15].  
- **Goldman Sachs**: Projects high-teens percentage gains for 2026, citing earnings growth and AI tailwinds [15].  
- **Cautionary Views**: Mohamed El-Erian warns of a "tense tug-of-war" between economic scenarios, noting K-shaped recovery and labor market stagnation risks [1][5].

**Summary**  
The February-March outlook hinges on three pillars:  
1. **Tech Earnings**: AI spending commitments must validate 2026 growth projections [6][13][20].  
2. **Fed Credibility**: Warsh's testimony must reassure markets of policy independence [2][9][10].  
3. **Data Resilience**: Jobs/inflation reports must align with soft-landing expectations [4][17].  

While near-term volatility is likely, **analysts broadly retain positive 2026 targets** (7,500-8,100) assuming earnings growth materializes and Fed transitions smoothly [11][12][15]. Markets will remain reactive to geopolitical shocks and political pressure on the Fed [5][14][19].
